awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF-P/Collaborative Research: Anthropocentric Robot Collaboration in Construction
awd_abstract_narration:
Labor-intensive construction accounts for a significant portion of the U.S. economy. However, construction suffers from significant occupational injuries/deaths, stagnant productivity, a lack of skilled laborers, and an aging workforce. As one means to address these issues, the construction industry is gradually adopting robotic automation, particularly in human-robot collaboration where humans and robots work together in unstructured and dynamic construction environments. Despite recent advancement of the functionality and capability of robots, many fundamental questions in human-robot collaboration remain unanswered. These include: 1. How can a robot work with a human worker, and build and maintain trust when they work together in the same space? 2. What are the best strategies to design future construction tasks and work environments for such human-robot collaboration? 3. How can the construction industry retrain existing workers and attract new ones in this new and unprecedented working environment? To answer these questions, this project carries out a human-centered investigation where a human worker's response to different scenarios of human-robot collaboration in construction is non-invasively and continuously monitored in order to maximize the overall performance of human-robot collaboration. The outcome of the investigation has the potential to build foundational knowledge on how we can prepare our existing and new workforce for future construction. 

Researchers have identified three major open research areas in human-robot construction. First is the in-depth understanding of human's physical, cognitive and emotional response in human-robot collaboration, a critical knowledge in allowing a robot's adaptable behaviors to be calibrated to a human response. Second is to explore how to redesign construction tasks, operations, and job sites to better serve human-robot collaboration. Studying such designs could involve a significant number of tests in the real world which may be impractical or infeasible, thus innovative testing technologies and methods are needed. Third involves strategies for training new and existing workers for future human-robot collaborative construction. In this project, researchers will test the feasibility of the three following research activities in the context of the above research areas: 1) testing wearable biosensors to non-invasively and continuously measure a human worker's emotional response in human-robot collaboration; 2) investigating the feasibility of virtual reality as an alternative to certain real construction tests for redesigning tasks and job sites for human-robot collaboration; and 3) organizing two workshops to collect broad perspectives from different stakeholders and experts to refine research thrusts for future human-robot collaboration in construction. The ultimate goal of this project is to develop the necessary research personnel, research infrastructure, and foundational work to expand the opportunities for studying future technology, future workers, and future work at the level of a FW-HTF full research proposal.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this NSF research is to achieve anthropocentric human-robot collaboration (HRC) in construction, making future construction more inclusive, safer, and more productive.

 

To this end, the project team studied cross-profession (workers versus managers) as well as cross-specialization (structural versus architectural finishing) stakeholders’ perceptions of HRC in the construction domain. The team performed qualitative data analysis on the responses on the semi-structured interviews and examined which contextual factors, job-related factors in particular, shaped stakeholder perceptions of robot adoption. The team found out that each group’s unique job-related factors influenced their perceived usefulness (PU), perceived output quality (POQ), perceived job relevance (PJR), and perceived ease of use (PEOU) of robotic technology, and consequently altered their views on desired robot abilities and preferred levels and types of HRC. For example, the desired robot role, which was highly related to POQ, depended on the variety of skills and subtasks required to complete the job. The safety risk, on the other hand, associated with the job influenced their desired level of autonomy, which was related to PU. Based on these findings we derived practical implications for construction robot deployment in varied construction situations.

In addition, this NSF project extends the outcome to bring researchers and practitioners together to address the question of how construction robots can be better designed and implemented to the existing workplaces by conducting a half-day workshop on the Future of Construction Robotics, where 109 participants of a wide range of groups including, but not limited to, professors, researchers, students, and construction industry people, participated in the workshop. Acknowledging the multidisciplinary nature of construction robotics, four speakers of different professionals in the domain, namely Henning Roedel (Innovation Team and Robotics Lead, DPR Construction), Brian Ringley (Construction Technology Manager, Boston Dynamics), SangHyun Lee (Professor, University of Michigan), and Robert M. Leicht (Associate professor, Pennsylvania State University), were invited to present their current work and share their visions on the future of construction robotics. The team held a panel discussion to explore how we could seek collaborative research opportunities to redesign the current construction process to achieve safe and effective human-robot collaboration.

This NSF project offers a multi-perspective on anthropocentric robot collaboration and establishes the foundation of future workplace design principles. The findings will discover how the current workforce will perceive and learn the new skills needed to interact with these technologies. Thus, the outcomes will enable broad and diverse workforce participation, for especially those who are untrained in robotics and have little experience with robots.

The findings from this NSF project were also broadly disseminated to the construction industry and academia through publications, and presentations. In addition, this project provided training for a number of graduate and undergraduate students, particularly from underrepresented groups, by involving them in research activities.
